children.subject: You should be fine then. The proofs in 170 aren't very hard (very hand-wavey at times) and many topics from 61b repeat.

history.content:
The two things that CS 70 are important for CS170 are:

  • Have you taken 61B? Are you familiar with basic data structures, e.g. graphs? Asymptotic analysis?
  • What's your math background? How comfortable are you with proofs?

children.subject:
I agree with the post above^, graph theory is super important from 70 but if you have a pretty solid understanding and just read the notes on graph theory from 70, you should be up to pace.

However, I would also extremely stress the importance of knowing how to write mathematical proofs (esp. induction and specifically graph theory proofs) because 170 expects you to write proofs all the time. A good chunk of questions in every single homework and in midterms/finals requires a 4 part solution: main idea, psuedocode for an algorithm, a proof of correctness, and a runtime analysis. And the proof of correctness is often the hardest part of each of these questions, since you need to take an abstract (often graph theory related) idea you have, break it down, and prove it using a mathematical proof.

Hm, it's interesting that you think that.

70 doesn't really spend much time on graphs (Sahai doesn't cover them at all), and also not in ways that are generally that relevant to 170. Like, 70 doesn't usually discuss cliques, and 170 doesn't mention planar graphs (the only related specific topic is Eulerian paths). 61B has a much stronger overlap in terms of graphs than 170 (to the extent that 170 has been skimming through some of the early graph material very quickly). More graph experience would certainly help, but I'm surprised to hear 70 as making a meaningful difference.

But yes, proofs (e.g. induction) are important.

How comfortable are you with graphs?

As a student that took 170 before 70, the only thing from 70 that I believe would have benefited me was more experience with graphs and graph terminology. I didn't know what cliques or planar graphs where, and while such concepts weren't vital to all parts of cs170, having prior knowledge of them certainly would have helped me.

If you're confident in your math background, and you're confident with your 61b knowledge in analyzing and creating novel data structures, then it shouldn't be too bad to take 170 before 70.

history.content:
I'm  MechE (so haven't taken CS 70) but I have taken EE 127 / 16A / 16B (as far as mathematical maturity goes). 

Is it a bad idea to take 170 next semester?
history.subject: Taking 170 w/o 70
